Award.AwardTitle: Phase-I: Internships and Scholarships to Promote Technological Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Teacher Education at SUNY College at Brockport's Science Education Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The State University of New York at Brockport is developing and implementing resources and methodologies to improve technological pedagogical content knowledge in teacher education. The project is using resources and computational mathematics, science, and technology (C-MST) courses, developed under previous grants, to improve teacher education. It emphasizes the recently developed conceptual framework, technological pedagogical content knowledge that has now put both science educators and computational scientists on the same path to utilize an interdisciplinary approach to STEM and teacher education. Strong content knowledge (via a STEM degree), extensive field experience (150 hours), student teaching, dual certification (science and special education), computational pedagogy courses, monetary support in the form of internships and scholarships, and a capstone summer institute construct a set of coherent strategies to attract, prepare, and retain a new cadre of 40 secondary school science teachers. The project is informed by a formative evaluation to enable frequent reviews and mid-course corrections and is disseminating its findings and resources through articles, conference papers and the project's website. The curriculum framework and learning modules are shared with national digital library collections contributing to teacher education nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The latest learning theories suggest that students learn better if they are engaged in activities closely resembling the way experts think and work. Accordingly, recent national K-12 learning objectives recommend constructivist activities to teach students experts’ habits of mind. This is not an easy task because of prerequisite content knowledge and practice skills needed to engage novices in the same thinking processes as experts, not to mention the cost of providing a similar environment to conduct inquiry and design.

By linking experts’ habits of mind to fundamental cognitive processes, this project makes is possible to narrow experts’ skillsets down to basic competencies that can be taught to novices. This outcome has resulted from a model of “how we think and learn,” arrived at through empirical data collected from teachers and students in this and other NSF projects by the principal investigator. Shown in Fig. 1, this model is consistent with neuroscientific and cognitive ways of information storage, retrieval, and processing that is done by our computational brains.

Linking cognition to computation (i.e., information processing) is not a new idea. In fact, it is what led Alan Turing to design the first electronic computing machines 80 years ago to imitate the human brain. Electronic computers have since taken many complex and voluminous computations off our brains, further supporting the view of brain as a biological computational device. Today, they have evolved to showcase many structural and functional similarities with the brain. These similarities arise from quantifiable aspects of information constructs, as suggested by Alan Turing, and the appearance of a universal mechanism (Fig. 1) by which quantifiable things form and evolve. That is, like the granular matter, information constructs either unite associatively, as shown by the bottom-up arrows in Fig. 1, to make bigger constructs or break down distributively, as shown by the top-down arrows, to smaller ones. Computing devices, be it electronic or biological, use similar ways to track and tally this invariant behavior of information.

Continuing the legacy of Turing to focus on device-independent processes (see Fig. 2), this project discovered new links between computation and cognition by identifying common patterns of information processing that are known to facilitate thinking. This has given us a framework to suggest a universal definition of computational thinking – i.e., thinking generated and facilitated by computation, regardless of the device that does the computation – along with an electronic computing methodology to facilitate relevant cognitive processes in schools.

Modeling and simulation (M&S) appears to be such a device-independent process of information employed by both electronic and biological computing devices to facilitate cognition. Everyone heavily uses M&S by the virtue of having a computational mind. Its cognitive mechanism works exactly as shown in Fig. 1 to generate conceptual change through iterative and cyclical use of associative (inductive) processing  and distributive (deductive) processing  of information. Through years of data collection in this project, we have concluded that teaching through M&S, via electronic computers, can facilitate this learning process further.

Accordingly, this project prepared 60 teachers who can teach STEM topics using M&S tools. The project has developed five new courses for pre-service students, a summer PD for in-service teachers, and a database of lesson plans and curriculum modules that are being downloaded at a rate of 50-100 by teachers around the country. The project produced two dozen articles that can help educators elsewhere to replicate or scale up this program to the national level. Among those, two award-winning articles introduced to the literature the notion of computational pedagogy and computational pedagogical content knowledge development framework for teacher professional development. Our model of how we learn and think has also enabled us to suggest a new framework (see Fig. 3) to describe the essence of computational, scientific and engineering thinking (experts' habits of mind).

The outcomes of this project could impact the entire STEM education. We call upon the STEM community to put more emphasis on M&S as a crucial part of student practice and education. Also, prior to teaching students computational skills, we need to teach them a habit of conceptual change through iterative and cyclical practices of inductive and deductive reasoning. Besides M&S tools, researchers should explore other modular and scalable design toys as well as reading and writing practices to offer similar practices.
